symbolism: The Minotaur has proven one of mythology's most symbolically rich figures, inspiring interpretation from antiquity to the present day:
domains: Monstrosity, the labyrinth, human sacrifice, divine punishment, the beast within humanity
symbols: Bull horns, the labyrinth spiral, the double axe (labrys), Cretan palace iconography
attributes: Asterion ("Starry One") - a name shared with Minos's stepfather, the previous king of Crete
Half-man, half-bull - with the head and tail of a bull upon a massive human body; a creature of unnatural birth, neither fully beast nor man
Born of Queen Pasiphae and the Cretan Bull, through Poseidon's curse upon King Minos
Monstrosity, the labyrinth, human sacrifice, divine punishment, the beast within humanity
Bull horns, the labyrinth spiral, the double axe (labrys), Cretan palace iconography
The Labyrinth at Knossos - an inescapable maze constructed by Daedalus
Asterion ("Starry One") - a name shared with Minos's stepfather

origin: Born of Queen Pasiphae and the Cretan Bull, through Poseidon 's curse upon King Minos
habitats: The Labyrinth at Knossos - an inescapable maze constructed by Daedalus
primarySources: Life of Theseus by Plutarch (c. 75 CE)
weaknesses: Mirrors: Cannot see her own reflection without petrifying herself
Indirect Vision: Can be fought by reflecting her gaze or using periphery
Mortal Body: Despite her powers, her physical form can be wounded
Emotional Vulnerability: Attachment can cloud her judgment
mythology_story: The tale of the Minotaur is one of broken vows, divine vengeance, and ultimately heroic triumph. It begins not with the monster itself, but with a king's hubris and a god's wrath. When the time came for the third tribute, Theseus , the young prince of Athens and son of King Aegeus (or of Poseidon himself, by some accounts), volunteered to join the sacrificial group. He swore to his father that he would slay the monster and end Athens's shame forever. If he succeeded, he would raise white sails on his return; if he perished, the ship would bear black sails of mourning.
abilities: Petrifying Gaze: Anyone who looks directly at her face turns instantly to stone
Serpent Hair: Living, venomous snakes that writhe and strike independently
Flight: Golden wings enable swift aerial movement
name: Greek Mythology
nature: Half-man, half-bull - with the head and tail of a bull upon a massive human body; a creature of unnatural birth, neither fully beast nor man
habitat: Solitary caves and temples, places of desolation
behavior: Victim turned protector, vengeful yet sympathetic, isolation-driven

christian.overview: The Minotaur's imprisonment in the labyrinth and slaying by Theseus provided rich material for Christian allegory about Christ's descent into death and victory.

biblicalParallels.description: The Minotaur fed on human tribute parallels sin's demand for death.
Christ entering death to destroy him who has power of death parallels Theseus entering the labyrinth.

patristicInterpretation.summary: The labyrinth represents sin's snares; the thread represents Christ maintaining divine connection.

medievalSymbolism.bestiaryMeaning: The Minotaur represents bestial sin in the labyrinth of the fallen heart.
medievalSymbolism.cathedrals: Cathedral floor labyrinths invited meditation on the soul's journey.

christian.typologicalReading: Prefigures the Harrowing of Hell: Christ descends, defeats death, leads captives free.
scholarlyReferences: Doob, Penelope Reed. The Idea of the Labyrinth. 1990.
